awd_titl_txt: Visionary Interdisciplinary Teams Advancing Learning (VITAL) Prize Competition Stage 2 Training
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will design and implement an eight-week entrepreneurial program for approximately 100 participating teams (each consisting of three researchers within the educational and learning technology field) focused on finding problem-solution fit and developing a minimum viable product (MVP). The training and curriculum proposed will be based on teachings from the NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps™) program and the Lean Startup pedagogy that focuses on the identification of a business model. The curriculum will teach value propositions, stakeholder identification, methods to build customer relationships, and distribution processes. These educational sessions will be interspersed with customer discovery activities as well as interviews with industry experts to expand the teams’ awareness of the educational/commercial ecosystem. This experience has the potential to provide all teams with the resources and foundational tools necessary to move their proposed innovations in learning and technology out of the lab and into the market.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: National Collegiate Inventors and Innovators Alliance
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: NATIONAL COLLEGIATE INVENTORS & INNOVATORS ALLIANCE, INC.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: National Collegiate Inventors and Innovators Alliance

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) established the Visionary Interdisciplinary Teams Advancing Learning (VITAL) Prize Competition with the aim of maximizing the transformation of NSF's basic research funding into practical applications that benefit society. The program builds on the recognition that lab-based innovators need formal training to evaluate whether their discoveries have potential commercial viability. 

 

The 2023 VITAL Prize Competition was focused on the education ecosystem. VITAL’s ultimate goal was to support early-stage innovators with the skills, tools, and resources necessary to fully understand the needs and parameters of the educational landscape. While this was introduced as a new program, it was inspired by established training models such as I-Corps, IUCRC, and SBIR, which have successfully supported inventors in market discovery for many years. 

 

VentureWell developed a framework for an initial round for the competition that would be rooted in an intensive and practical learning experience, as well as individualized coaching, for the cohort of teams. This Discovery Round was designed to expose all entering teams to core principles of innovation and entrepreneurship, to provide them with a methodology and a framework to discover key features of the education market they seek to enter, to increase their chances of being competitive in future rounds of the challenge, and to give them a strong knowledge base for any future endeavors in their path toward successful entrepreneurship.

 

Digital Promise was the partner organization that received applications and selected the initial cohort of 100 teams to enter the competition, based on three areas of specialization: Rapid and Continuous Learning Assessment, Mathematical Literacy, and other innovations in Translational Learning Technologies. VentureWell partnered with Digital Promise to take these teams through the Discovery Round, and at its completion, passed along a select group of successful teams back to Digital Promise for the subsequent rounds.

 

The Discovery Round consisted of an eight-week training focused on finding problem-solution fit and developing a minimum viable product. VentureWell designed a curriculum to meet the needs of participating teams, drawing from existing, proven training models. Four Subject Matter Experts were contracted to deliver curriculum content to all participants, as well as ten coaches to conduct office hours and support individual teams in their progress. Teams had the opportunity to learn from these SMEs in synchronous and recorded sessions, on subjects such as Customer Discovery, Market Segmentation, Prototyping, and Storytelling. Teams were also assigned a coach to provide individualized guidance as they progressed from week to week.

Teams were expected to engage in customer discovery, in order to gain experience in the research method of interviewing as a way to learn about customer needs, expectations, and pain points. As they progressed, teams also created presentation materials to share with coaches and track their own findings. VentureWell designed and provided tools for this record-keeping and for the interactive portions of the training.

 

The Discovery Round concluded with a final pitch presentation allowing teams to share their findings and receive a final evaluation. Using an evaluation rubric, judges assessed teams' eligibility for advancement to the next round of the VITAL Prize. They evaluated the teams for the work accomplished, the ability to present a prototype and its potential market fit, the level of impact it might have on the education landscape, as well as other criteria. Out of the original 100 teams, 54 were selected to advance to the next round.

 

In order to assess the success of the initial run of the program, VentureWell designed and implemented a pre-course evaluation survey of all Discovery Round participants. The pre-course evaluation provided a baseline view of the knowledge base of the entering cohort of teams, before participating in the program. At the conclusion of the program, participants were again surveyed about their knowledge gains, their assessment of the quality of instruction, and the implementation of the program. Respondents in these surveys reported an increase in knowledge gain related to (1) their capacity to articulate various customer segments and their distinctive attributes and (2) their proficiency in describing the market size of their products. Many also reported increases in their sense of preparedness for technology commercialization, and in their own confidence. 

 

Through the VITAL Prize Discovery Round, VentureWell was able to offer the 100 entering teams, which comprised over 400 participants, an intensive experience with foundational concepts of entrepreneurship and customer discovery, as well as individual guidance, giving them the opportunity to increase their odds of advancing through the later stages of the competition. Even more broadly, regardless of the outcome of any individual pitch within the VITAL competition, all of the skills acquired by the participants were designed to be translatable and applicable to any future entrepreneurial endeavors. 

 


Last Modified: 12/08/2023
Modified by: Philip J Weilerstein
